data.title: Scheduling exercise diversifies as Spiders prepare for Patriot League move
meta_keywords: ncaa division i football bowl subdivision
ncaa division i fbs football teams
data.meta_description: Richmond is not joining the Patriot League for football until next season, but scheduling activity associated with the move from CAA Football is already underway.
data.text:
The puzzle Stephen Butler assembles has changed a bit.

Butler is the University of Richmond deputy athletic director who supervises football scheduling. That translates to nonconference scheduling, because leagues determine members’ conference slates.

Richmond is not joining the Patriot League for football until next season, but scheduling activity for the move from CAA Football is already underway at the Robins Center.

Numbers game

The Spiders have annually played eight CAA Football games and three or four nonconference games, depending on whether the calendar year allowed for 11 or 12 regular-season games. A dozen games are permitted for FCS programs by the NCAA, but not required, when there are 13 Saturdays between Labor Day weekend and Thanksgiving.

The Patriot League will include eight teams after UR arrives, so there will be seven conference games and four or five nonconference dates for the Spiders each season.

Future FBS opponents

Butler’s scheduling job typically begins with what FBS opponents the Spiders will face, and that’s North Carolina next season, N.C. State in 2026, Louisville in 2027, Virginia in 2028, Pittsburgh in 2029 and Virginia again in 2031. This season, on Aug. 31, the Spiders open at Virginia.

“We kind of sit right in the sweet spot for ACC opponents. We can get to a bunch of them with a relative ease of travel,” said Butler. “Virginia and Carolina ACC schools we are in discussions with, and certainly that includes UNC, N.C. State, Duke, Wake Forest and Virginia.”

W&M rivalry

With UR’s pending departure from CAA Football, the Spiders remain highly interested in annually facing CAA member and rival William & Mary.

“We have had very productive conversations with William & Mary to have that series continue for the foreseeable future,” Butler, who joined the UR staff in 2023 after 12 years at Niagara, said Tuesday.

UR-W&M has historically been played on the final Saturday of the regular season. That will no longer happen, with the programs obligated to league games at that time. The schools are trying to find an agreeable date in 2025, during which the Spiders outside of seven Patriot League games will face UNC, VMI, Wofford and Howard in a year when 12 regular-season games are permitted.

Schedule strength

To put the future Spiders teams in position for FCS at-large bids in the 24-team playoffs, UR began working on upgrading its nonconference schedule before the move to the Patriot League was announced in mid-May, according to Butler.

That strategy was associated with CAA Football changes (additions of Bryant, Monmouth, North Carolina A&T, Hampton and Campbell, while James Madison went to FBS and Delaware will go to FBS next summer) that decreased the league’s strength.

“As we were looking at the CAA, quite frankly last year’s strength of schedule was lower than we’ve had,” Butler said. “Some folks might point to the Patriot League and say, ‘Oh, you’ve really got to strengthen your nonconference schedule.’ But I think that practice was already happening in the CAA, because we played a strength of schedule that was lesser than some of our conference peers in the CAA.”

CAA Football includes 16 teams this season. Eight league opponents for each member are determined on a rotating basis.

“From a Richmond standpoint, we are doing everything we can to put ourselves in position for postseason. Certainly, that’s contending for conference championships and getting the automatic bid, but it’s also an at-large (bid), too,” Butler said. “So, we’re constantly monitoring those metrics.”

Coach’s perspective

Russ Huesman, who’s in his eighth season as Spiders coach, is easy to work with in nonconference scheduling, according to Butler, because he is willing to play just about any opponent. Before becoming UR’s coach, Huesman spent eight years as Chattanooga’s coach, and during his tenure with the Mocs, they played at Alabama three times (2016, ‘13, ‘09), at Florida State (2015), at Tennessee (2014), at Auburn (2010) and at Nebraska (2011).

On the FCS front, Southern Conference member Furman will play at Richmond in 2026 before welcoming the Spiders to Paladin Stadium in 2027. Butler said UR will focus on the potential of playing nonconference opponents that regularly finish in the top half of their FCS leagues.
